Comment: The problem is really with people who when they heard this joke, took it to be about racism, rather than about the archaic term "Master".

It is clear that the context for the remark was the ongoing discussion of the appropriateness of the term "master".

What makes it *irony* is that those who were once oppressed are now Fellows sitting at the "Master"s" table. No one is making fun of them, or gloating over their past oppression, Prof. Marcus was commenting on the changed social circumstances from the time when the term "master" would have been taken literally.

Who in their right mind can think that this was meant to be insulting? How? Was he supposed to be "rubbing it in" or making fun of them for belonging to a once enslaved group? Really?!

Comment: Nice to see the comments feature return. 

Much of the difficulty that culminated in the feature's deletion could have been obviated by active moderatorship. As with anything, there is no free lunch: benefits come with costs. In the case of a comments section, the benefits were crystal clear. Civic engagement and, from the publication's perspective, the generation of incredibly valuable ledes. Remember the infamous W. Howard? That story would literally have had no legs were it not for the comments feature. We all remember the other details that came out solely because people leaked information via commentary on published stories. 

Seems like the baby got thrown out with the bathwater. In any event, we'll see how this pans out and I hope for the best.

On a separate note, I'm eyeballing the quickly dwindling "characters left" ticker here. I appreciate brevity, but you may want to consider increasing this if you want commentary that is thoughtful, not just "civil." Just a thought.

Comment: Pension plans are regulated by governments, either provincial or federal, through minimum pension standards legislation (think employment standards minimums for pensions).  Those standards have changed over the last 30 years. Most provinces have now moved minimum standards legislation to require that a member who leaves a plan after 2 years of participation are entitled to receive a pension benefit based on both employer and employee contributions. Some provinces now have immediate vesting of the benefit. So the 10 year rule in this comment is not accurate. 
I also question why an employee who has no or little experience with investing over the course of their career would expect to do better than people who do it for their living. Perhaps they feel better that they have control over their money, but the article suggests that people expect to make way more than is realistic. Most don't understand the huge impact that 2% fees charged have on the value of their benefit in the long term

Comment: The Alaska market is open. The problem is who wants to spend the money to enter our tiny, risky, expensive, Alaska market when nobody even knows what the rules will be next year. Insurance companies are already locked into premiums for next year, but Trump hasn't decided if he will fund the premium subsidies and deductible reductions that insurers will be committed to shortly. Trump has also not committed to whether the mandate will be enforced or not. Without the mandate, the risk pool gets sicker and more expensive to insure. Companies have to have at least three or four years of predictable rules and funding commitments before they will commit to the expense of entering a new market. Call it the Trump tax on people that buy insurance.

Comment: I will just say this, too. Much of that extended training for doctors is in all facets of medicine. The psychiatrist has had at least one rotation through endocrinology, cardiology, and surgery, etc. NP education is focused on one area. It makes sense that we do not take as long to complete our education. Some kind of externship/mentoring program/residency after graduation is also reasonable. But too many places do not have such programs in place.  NPs do have the same courses in Advanced Pathophysiology, Policy and Politics, and other "core courses", but as an NP student, I did not have to have rotations through other disciplines. In my undergraduate program, I completed clinicals in all aspects. But one can practice as an RN with an Associate's Degree. To take it up to the level of being able to diagnose, treat, and prescribe, the education is more focused. I am glad that an increasing number of facilities are seeing the need for some kind of residency

Comment: Washington Examiner  2013

"To see how meaningless the career-vs.-political distinction can be at the IRS, consider the case of Mark Ernst. He was H&R Block's CEO as recently as 2007, but when Obama took office in January 2009, Ernst joined the IRS as a deputy commissioner and helped craft new regulations governing tax preparers -- H&R Block and its competitors. How did this not violate Obama's revolving-door rules? "Mark Ernst is a civil servant at the IRS," an IRS spokesman explained to me. "He is not a political appointee."

But Ernst had spent decades in the private sector. He came in with the new administration. His stint at the IRS lasted less than two years. And he certainly was political: Federal Election Commission records show he contributed more than $49,000 to federal candidates and political action committees. His donations favor Democrats.
 
So, being a "career civil servant" doesn't mean you're making a career out of the job, or that you're not political."

Comment: What matters, surely, is per capita GNP growth, not simply GNP growth? However,  McKenna doesn't specifically address per capita GNP growth.  India and China have much larger GNPs than Canada, but much lower per capita GNP. Lots of  people most of whom are poor tend to produce that mathematical result. Trump's proposal, as I understand it, wasn't to reduce the number of skilled immigrants to the US but to reduce the number of family category immigrants (as opposed to just spouses and underage children). One might plausibly argue that increasing the number of skilled immigrants even more would increase US per capita GNP and would be the rational thing to do   However, it is less clear how admitting fewer aged relatives would decrease per capita GNP,  even in a country that, unlike Canada, lacks universal health care, or, for that matter, how admitting fewer aged relatives would decrease the number of candidates for low paying unpleasant jobs.

Comment: Good read Michael.  I was in country while you were taking your finals.  There is the old Indian fable about the blind men each holding a different piece of an elephant and trying to describe it.  I surmise, that is what you get, when you open up the discussion about "The American War".  I first heard this term used in 2012, when I was visiting Nha Trang and was sitting in a restaurant looking at the water in the bay.  A Vietnamese gentleman saw me looking out and said in English, "that is a very nice view" and I said, "Yes it is. The last time I saw this view was 45 years ago". He looked at me and said "you were in the American War?".  He, then asked to sit down with me.  Which I said sure and we had a 45 minute conversation. Comment: I'm not sure what you mean when you say the Ordinary Form isn't protected. It is the only liturgy one is likely to encounter in the vast majority of Catholic churches throughout the world. Those who follow the Tridentine Rite are more likely to have a Catholic understanding of the Mass than those who attend the so-called Ordinary Form.
Near me a group of Irish schoolchildren visiting England attended Sunday Mass at an Anglican Church which advertised its Sunday service as High Mass. The vicar, a friend of mine, told me that they left at the end completely unaware that they had not attended a Catholic Mass.

Comment: The AR in “AR-15” rifle stands for ArmaLite, after the company that developed the
firearm in the 1950s. “AR” does NOT stand for “assault rifle” or “automatic rifle.”

AR-15 and other semi-automatic rifles, which fire one round with each pull of the trigger, are NOT “assault weapons” or “assault rifles.” An assault rifle is fully automatic -- amachine gun. Automatic firearms have been severely restricted from civilian ownership since 1934. 

If someone calls an AR-15 or other semi-automatic rifle an “assault weapon,” he or
she either supports banning these firearms or does not understand their function and 
sporting use, or both. Please correct them. “Assault weapon” is a political term created
by California anti-gun legislators to ban some semi-automatic rifles there in the 1980s

Comment: The Earth's climate has been changing for ~4.5B years, without the help of humans.

 It would be interesting, if those who are claiming humans caused climate change, to provide some scientific data as to how just how much, humans are contributing, in comparison to natural variability. 

 Is it 1%/99%, 50%/50%, 99%/1%? 
Natural gas, as does coal combustion,  produces greenhouse gases such as H2O, CO2, etc.
One of the simplest way to note significant global temperature change is noting sea levels. Oceans cover most of the earth's surface, & H2O expands with temperature. If there would be abnormal heating, sea level increases would show an acceleration in their rise (going on since the last ice age).

Long term sea level tidal gauge date shows a virtually straight line rise over the last 100+ years, indicating that pretty much all the climate change is due to natural variations.

Prescribing drugs for the wrong, or no illness, can be dangerous.

Comment: I disagree completely with this article, and Canada does NOT have the best electoral system in the world, which is the basic assumption you have to accept for the rest to make sense... including the undeserved Harper worship. BTW the 'national party' the writer lauds under Harper didn't win a single seat in four provinces and three territories. In the status quo, regardless of what you believe, you are herded to vote CPC, or Liberal. An NDP vote is a protest vote, and voting Green even more so.... not my party, but in 2008 they got almost a million votes, 7% of the popular vote, and no seats. If some sort of blended PR system was adopted, those voices would get some representation, and that would grow as people wouldn't feel compelled to vote for or against the Cons or the Libs. And if that leads to minority governments, good; we have had our best governance under minority governments.

In 2015 every party but one campaigned on and backed a change from FPTP. They were right.

Comment: "To maintain current levy programs like advanced placement classes, tutor buses and athletics, we would be forced to run a new local levy."

I love the use of the term "forced" here.  It takes the onus off the schools and puts it on us - the taxpayer.  There is nobody "forcing" the school district to put another levy on the ballot.  But Mr. Johnson seems to make it sound like he has to do it.  

Another idea floated by the legislature was to raise the cap on property tax increases from 1% to 5% per year.  Over the next 10 years many folks could see their property taxes nearly double.

I have a better idea.  Why not remove education funding from property taxes completely.  Instead the state should institute an income tax (weighted on the upper end earners) that pays entirely for the education system in Washington.  This is much more fair than a property tax system that promotes better schools in areas with higher home prices.

Food for thought.....

Comment: Claimed copies, the authenticity of which cannot be confirm, are not 'copies that exist' by any sane definition of that concept. They are not evidence by any scientific standard of the term 'evidence'.

None exist.

To say one existed, to claim evidence for it, you need either the original - or one that is verifiably an accurate copy from the original (or at the very least a verifiably accurate copy of a copy that was off the original and probably accurate).

Even if these copies were not in dispute as to their authenticity - we have absolutely no evidence that their content actually matches the originally. Hand-copying is notoriously unreliable and you frequently end up with important changes as the copying party alters things to suit his personal agenda.
It can even happen innocently. Monks who copied the bible for centuries often made notes in the margine. More than a few of those notes are now, likely, included in the main text because somebody later on didn't know they were notes

Comment: I spent 20 years in the U.S. I got rather perturbed at their superpatriotism, and the "historic" stories they believed in to support it. Then I came back to this country, and came to realize that we have absolutely no founding myths that unite us, only founding myths that divide us. The Plains of Abraham? The Charlottetown Conference? The Riel Rebellion? Whatever interpretation you make of any of these will wave a red flag in the face of some faction or other in Canada, as witness the current controversy over The Story of Us.

I have come to suspect, reluctantly, that there is something to be said for a country to have a body of historical myths that everyone believes in, these common beliefs creating a fellow feeling among people of different origins and holding the culture together -- even if every single one of those myths is a ramping, stamping, thumping lie, as is the case with the Americans.

Stephen M. Bowell

Comment: Really a great skill to work with in any relationship.   I've done mediation between juvenile offenders and their victim.   First process is for each to tell their story about the crime and what they were thinking/feeling.   The learning starts as each has to repeat what they heard and they go through that until both agree on the story.   They the second person speaks and tells their story, Same process, same repeat what you heard.... 

The amazing thing about that type of mediation is the sense of a connection that it builds between the victim and the offender.   My roll was to keep the process in focus, not to solve the mediation.     It is amazing to see how many times the offender feels remorse (most had no idea of the effect of say a small robbery), and suggest a harsh correction in their 'contract' with the victim, only for the victim to forgive them and build a more relational solution.   We went from crime the start of friendship.

Thank you for this series Sharon

Comment: Gotta agree with the logic of Megaladon, the COTU unit worked well for the slopes needs for +40 years.  This small footprint distillation process has no waste by products.  Residue oil, after the diesel is distilled out is put back into the Slope production line.  COTU cannot meet the ultra low sulfur EPA requirements, needed for the lower 48.  Even if COTU could take the sulfur out, there is nothing the Slope can do with this by-product.  To use tankers going up the haul road from Nikiski or Valdez and returning empty is absolutely nuts.  I can assure you the Russian Arctic oil fields are not hauling diesel +800 miles and then sending tanker trucks back +800 miles to a refinery empty.  This is one EPA rule that some bureaucrat needs to issue a variance for North Slope's COTU.  Roll-overs and diesel air and ground spill pollution along the road from Valdez or Nikiski are going to continue until someone uses common sense.

Hate crimes can be pretty hard to pin down, but they should be investigated where evidence exists because often there is an underlying wish to inspire others to engage in the same sort of actions. Comment: The article covers beers from Scotland and the south but misses the UK's best beer brewing region: Yorkshire. One of the best beers in the UK is Old Peculier. It's brewed in Masham, Yorkshire - although there was a period a few year ago when they also brewed it in Newcastle which is best forgotten about - and has a very long heritage dating back to the 1890's and has won national awards.

Black Sheep ales are another product of this small Yorkshire town and they have a great beer named Riggwelter which is a Yorkshire term for a sheep on its back and is unable to get up. Their Yorkshire Square Ale is also good and it's brewed using the Yorkshire Square fermenting system which dates back over 200 years.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Bond yields are half what they were in 2003, so that's why it's almost exactly the same carrying cost. Due to economic growth, the real impact is actually smaller - in 2003 it was 11b/80b total spending (about 14%), today it's 11b/130b (about 8%)  

Government bonds are like GICs, in that they don't reset until they mature. Ontario's been taking out 30 year bonds lately, so today's rates are basically "locked in" until the 2040s, by which point inflation will have significantly diminished their impact. 

For the same reason, if Ontario is issuing bonds today for 2.5%, and that goes up to 3.5, sounds like a hike, right? Except they're paying, on average, 4% .. and that's because the older debt is still there, at a higher rate.  What you get, is let's sasy 15 billion dollars of debt from 1997, paying 6%, which matures and rolls over at 3.5%, freeing up the 2.5% difference... reducing interest costs even though rates have increased slightly recently.

Comment: Pearce Bunting was the president of the Toronto Stock Exchange in the 1980's.  It was under his leadership that the TSE (as it was then) embarked on automating what was then called basket trading.  Being able to simultaneously buy or sell all the individual components of a basket of shares led to the advent of the Toronto 35 index and its related ETF  Institutional investors were also interested in developing programme trading using similar technology.  Toronto was a leader at the time having studied the programmed trading capabilities of the NYSE, Amex Exchange and CME.  Programme trading and basket trading led to ETF development.  Fun times!

Comment: Angus,

It's true that we'll only know in retrospect what the long term impact of Brexit was.

The start of this contraction of UK economic prospects post-referendum was delayed by (a) significant monetary easing by the Bank of England, (b) a devaluation of the Pound by more than 10%, & (c) early hopes that a 'soft' Brexit would be quickly negotiated. Comment: I believe you are exactly right:  AI will automate millions of jobs out of existence, beginning with driving-related ones over the next 5 - 10 years.  Office and knowledge workers will not be immune.  At first, it will be a gradual shift, where AI will take on an "assist" role: head-office will not lay off Tim in Finance to be replaced by a robot right away, but they won't hire that extra headcount or contract worker.  But with increasing workplace penetration, machine learning and algorithms will start improving exponentially, and eventually supplant more and more people.  I could see very significant impacts on employment and society within the next 15-20 years.  Is it reasonable to think that new jobs and professions will sprout to replace the old ones?  Maybe, but many (most) will remain under or unemployed. What will people do without meaningful work?  How will they pay for food and rent?  Brace for huge social unrest and accelerated wealth concentration at the top of the pyramid.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: As usual, the parties on both sides of this issue are using the Seattle experience to support their positions.

The real problem is, while we all agree that the minimum wage should be raised, both the why as well as the way in which it is being done by Kathleen Wynne and her Liberal buddies.

The Liberals are doing this mainly to buy votes in the next provincial election and as such have given little thought to the business ramifications of the increase.

It takes time to adjust for the extra payroll taxes, pension payments, benefits, etc. that are over and above the actual wage increase and to understand how these increased costs of doing business will impact individual businesses. 

I.E. Should one increase selling prices or layoff staff?

$15.00/hour is a worthy goal but let's get there with a smooth business transition that has been better planned..

There is little doubt that it is too much too soon and does not give businesses a chance to plan and adapt to the consequences.

Comment: Every initiative which is passed, just as every law passed by the legislature or ordinance passed by a local jurisdiction, is subject to judicial review if someone challenges it....this is hardly news.  However, as Mr. Workman notes, that is the responsibility of a Court, not of a County Commission.  

The Commissioners have "tabled" the measure for now and, in just under six months, we'll see if they wish to further pursue their ill-advised attempt to establish a preemptive veto power of County Initiatives.  Special interest groups have every opportunity to oppose an initiative as it's being circulated for signatures or, if it qualifies for the ballot, during the campaign for its passage. If an initiative passes which displeases a specific special interest group, the group has every opportunity to challenge the legality of the initiative.

Comment: I don't know who actually owns the land, but this went beyond just land ownership.  It was more like a zoning issue. Comment: Ms. Zachau-kirk,
Most of Ebey's Reserve is privately owned - a fact many folks don't understand.  Washington State owns acreage in the Reserve, including Fort Ebey, Fort Casey, and Ebey's Landing State Parks. The Federal Government owns around 500 acres within Ebey's Reserve - around 2% of the total  Reserve. But the outlying field and the buildings around the field are not within the Reserve.  The field lies just east of the boundary.  
The Reserve and the Navy sometimes have conflicting missions.  Most would argue that operational expansion at the OLF as proposed in the draft EIS is one of those times.  That is why all of the Reserve partners, and many local concerned citizens, exercised their responsibility to submit comments to the EIS expressing their individual concerns about the proposed increase.  At this point we all hope the folks back in Virginia make the right decisions with the final document, based on the information they have spent so much time and energy to gather.

Comment: "Reducing the amount of unused opioids out in the world, Valuck said, is “the biggest piece of low-hanging fruit in this whole thing.”"
Part of the problem is in the rules for opiod prescriptions. When going in for surgery, the prescription is written early, so that the pills can be in hand immediately after the surgery, and it is written for a one month supply, since it cannot be refilled any sooner. If you need the painkillers for a shorter period of time, you are left with pills that you have paid for and probably won't dispose of them, because you might need them at some future date.This makes for a lot of opiod medications sitting in medicine cabinets.

Comment: Caron has experience both in communications and economics. He is the one candidate who seems to me to have a credible fiscal plan - the best way to fend of the usual attacks that the NDP are feckless"tax-and-spend socialists".  In 2019, he is the candidate most likely to attract Quebec votes which as Layton showed can change everything.

Yes, there are many non-white voters who would seek a voice though Singh, who is without doubt a worthy, well spoken candidate. I wonder how many non-NDP voters would consider him in 2019 though? Given their attitudes to religious symbols, Singh would likely repel Quebec voters, who have shown in the past they would entertain the NDP, so the party has to estimate whether the likelihood of gains in BC and Ontario are worth the likely losses in Quebec.

With respect, I'm for Caron. Anyone with ambitions to lead government some day must be able to devise realistic fiscal plans and communicate why they make more sense that the alternatives.

Comment: The gain in the volume of wholesale trade reported is for the so-called chained 2007 dollar estimates, the chain Fisher estimates, a 0.7% increase in April after a 0.9% (actually 0.85%) increase in March. The Laspeyres volume estimates (at 2007 prices) more closely match the initial estimates for gross output of wholesale trade used to measure GDP for wholesale trade for April. These estimates showed even stronger growth (as one would expect): a 0.8% increase in April after a 0.9% increase in March. It was a good report and suggests there may be continued real GDP growth in April.

Comment: They could have sold and then just relisted - same agent.  Not illegal to do this. 

Shadow flipping of course involves a re-assignment of the contract before closing - great for avoiding land transfer taxes.  You can still "shadow flip" as long as the original buyer knows it is being done, and supposedly gets the profit.

On my street here in Richmond, a house listed at 1.8 and sold, then relisted at 2.4.  Then the price was 2.0...and now the price is at 2.3.  Three different agencies, and all in less than a year with no one ever living in the house. And for Richmond - not unusual.

Comment: When the chips are down, flimsy fabric rope lines would be infinitely preferable as a barrier between me and an exit than would the hard walls and more confined space of the proposed alternative.  With the current layout, you could run forward into the terminal train station, backward into Customs (if at north screening, or to the outdoor plaza if at the south checkpoint), or east or west toward baggage claim and various exits.  This ability to disperse in multiple directions also makes it more difficult for an attacker to continue to pursue potential victims.  The proposed, more corridor-like checkpoint on the other hand appears that it would confine passengers within hard walls in a narrower area.  With exits in that case only available forward through screening or backward through the entrance (and remember, the attackers would likely be coming from the direction of the entrance), options for escape would be far more limited.  This confinement also raises risk of trampling/jamming.

Comment: I really like the Bradley.  I have a bottom end model but there are real advantages to all Bradleys. 

Automatic bisquette feeder.  You can put many hours of bisquettes in at once. You do have to dump water pan every 2 1/2 - 3 hours though.  The idea is to never 'ash' the wood as it is detrimental to the flavour.  The bisquettes fall into the water to extinguish them. 

You can also 'cold smoke'. There is one burner to burn the bisquette and another for smoker temp. This allows smoking cheese without melting it or smoking bacon without melting the fat. 

Upper end models have thermostatic control. 

Bisquettes come in over 20 flavors. Even whiskey oak barrel, Jim Beam Bourbon and I saw a box of 'beer' flavor (infused into maple). 

I really enjoy it.

Comment: Not sure how long ago the out-flow of Grant Lake changed into the present channel near south end; but it has at some point as indicated by two turbulent areas that look to be large waterfalls which may have slowed salmon & trout from getting into that lake.
.
The original channel can be seen in google earth, as other older channels from flood stage outflow along the escarpment above (middle) Trail Lake; those perhaps from glacier thaw some hundred+ years ago. Evidence in rock can be harder to gauge, erosion may take longer to happen if the rock were harder than guessed.
.
The last time my travels were to the south end of Grant Lake, was March 1985 when I had a new Yamaha Bravo with incredible MPG & oil injection. After chem spill at C.P. RR siding. Three of us went up there in deep powder. A wall-tent on wooden platform was by Grant Creek headwaters. 
.
Previous visits had been on snowshoes; summer hikes, & notable one, on low-powered trailbike; early 1970s old mine via road/swamp.

I think it's too late to change your daughter-in-law. It's not too late to change yourself.

Comment: American courts have a long history of making reasonable accommodations for religious groups, but they are always subordinate to the U.S. Constitution and civil law. Halakha is one example of a such an accommodation. Tribal laws allowing the limited use of peyote on Indian reservations is another. One example of an unacceptable religious practice is polygamy which, while still practiced clandestinely by some Mormons, is outlawed.

Some aspects of Shariah are acceptable under U.S. law and others are not, and those who practice Shariah in this country do so voluntarily. Nobody in the U.S. has the legal right to impose their religious beliefs on another person or group, and when they do (as has happened from time to time) it is treated as a crime.

Believe me, I'm not starry-eyed about Shariah and I would not wish it on anyone I cared about, especially any woman. But the laws in this country already protect them. Extra legislation is unnecessary.

Comment: Steven Bell - How did discontinuing the emissions program hurt your wallet? You an IM specialist?

Up here in Fairbanks, emissions testing cost me a minimum of $200 every two years. That was in cash outlay, not counting the lost wages since you could never get a car emissions-tested on a Saturday, so I would have to take time off work. So $400, minimum. Then it cost us extra for the emissions tag when we renewed our registration. I don't know what sort of study Anchorage did before deciding to discontinue their program, but here in Fairbanks, a record check showed 98% of the cars were passing the tests without modification. So, basically, the emissions tests weren't catch many polluters but millions of dollars a year was being spent proving that we weren't polluting.

The "broken windows" theory of economics was eloquently refuted by Bastiat centuries ago. You might want to read his essay. https://mises.org/library/which-seen-and-which-not-seen.

Comment: 4% net yield before taxes on the RE? So after tax, it is probably (I'm guessing) closer to 3%?

I have investments in the stock market and over the years they've averaged 4.5 - 5.5 percent return. (For the most part, I don't go into anything that is very risky.) Yes, stock markets go up and down (recently mostly up). So if you are bothered about seeing your wealth evaporate in a downturn, you should probably stay away from stocks. 

As far as taxes go, if you can put your investments into an RRSP, you don't worry about taxes until down the road when, in theory, your income is lower. I don't think you can do that with a house, though maybe there is a clever way to do it. (Aside from your principal residence, of course.)

Lastly, my stocks don't stop paying rent, trash my place, need a new roof, etc. 

But I think your friends have the main ingredient in generating wealth--Money to invest.

The legislature sets the tone by funding, or withholding funding, of agency effort to effectively do their mandated work. For very many years, a culture has built up for the 'avoidance at any cost' of toxic contaminant monitoring unless some crisis in the media pushed a stop-gap blatant need. Agencies fear punitive legislative reductions of any agency that 'makes waves' by pointedly investigative work that could demonstrate ongoing toxic pollution for humans and wildlife. Legislatures erroneously see such investigatory monitoring as being inherently politically and fiscally subversive, but such work is essential.

Comment: Wynne didn't want this watchdog in the first place.

The creation of a Financial Accountability Officer for Ontario was one of the demands the Ontario NDP made before they would offer their support for the 2013 budget.  Since the Liberals had a minority at the time, and they were *FAR* away from getting the PC party to support them, the Liberals made several concessions in their budget in negotiations with the NDP.

The highest profile change was the promise to lower car insurance rates by 15%, but arguably the creation of the FAO was the most important change.

Comment: Perhaps you are misunderstand me:

In the Old Testament, the death penalty was used liberally and God did command the deaths of people.  In the New Testament, we do not see this.  This has lead people to jump to conclusions and claim that the God of the OT and the NT God must be two different gods, etc.  

I don't see it that way--but my position is not that God is commanding us to use the death penalty.  My position is that the death penalty can be morally justifiable in certain cases.  We are commanded to love, indeed.  God is, indeed love.  However---love of enemies must be balanced by the need to protect society as well as bring some semblance of justice to the victims of horrific crimes.  

You don't mean to tell me that you believe that Osama Bin Laden should not have been put to death do you?  You don't mean to tell me that God holds us in contempt for putting him to death, do you?

Comment: It's been 4 or 5 years since I've been in Boulder, but I don't remember any interesting architecture in the newer business areas; mostly new and trendy looking stuff, the same as can be found in almost any other city with comparable demographics.
Eugene does have some stunningly ugly buildings; the Hub takes first prize, but in my recollection Capstone, downtown LCC and OMG would fit just fine in Boulder and in most other mid-size cities.
Comparing Eugene and Boulder: well, when I first arrived in Eugene, many years ago, it reminded me of Boulder, except for a completely different climate. Now, the climates are still just as different, which probably has some effect on the built environment, but the disparity in wealth has grown dramatically and not in Eugene's favor.
In both places the "counter culture" was prominent back in the 70s and beyond, but also in both places, but I think more so in Boulder, "over the counter culture" has become dominant.

Comment: This sounds a lot like two previous Social Credit Programs.

When my wife and I bought a home at the bottom of the Real Estate Market Cycle in 1982 we assumed a 16% first mortgage (k$60 paid off in 5 years, 9 months) and took out a BC Home Program k$10 2nd mortgage for 8 months. 

The 16% rate was a bargain because the going rate was 20%. The interest rate was so high that the SoCred government came up with a ridiculous program of loans for every homeowner, subsidising the effective interest rate. Some people didn't realise that it was a loan and that a lien would be placed against their home.

My wife and I thought that it was a stupid waste of tax dollars, but we applied anyway, since every other BC home owner with a mortgage was doing the same thing. We invested the interest free loan money into Term Deposits, since we didn't need it. The SoCreds were so desperate to get the money back that we were able to pay off the loan at 90 ¢ on the $. Right Wing Nut fiscal policy in action.

Comment: While fed and some state tax incentives for both have existed for more than 40 years in the US, I think it may be too late for these alone to do much good in anything other than a continued growth/full employment scenario. In any other scenario, e.g. jobless growth and/or mostly low-wage job growth, 

not to mention various types of stagnation, decline, and collapse scenarios, profit sharing and employee stock ownership could not only be useless, but could also result in employees losing income (especially in the case of stock ownership).

However, had either become the norm, rather than the exception, in corporate American at least 30+ years ago, they may have reduced the increase in income inequality resulting from the combo of automation and outsourcing (job exportation to cheaper labor markets) over the same time period. 

Such incentives MIGHT still be useful before automation runs its potential full course, but probably less so for the growing number of gig economy workers

Comment: IRT to phone scammers.  I suggest signing up for Nomorobo.  I signed up for the Do Not Call List years ago, but, was still getting unsolicited calls.  When I signed up for Nomorobo, those unsolicited calls are ALMOST to zero.  Scammers are finding ways to get you to answer your phone.  The Nomorobo is on our landline, so, when we are watching TV, the caller's number comes on the TV screen, but the good thing is the phone rings only once.  That's how we know it is a scam.  Sometimes on our phone, it just says "Incoming Call" with the one ring.  
We notice the calls that are from credit card companies that wants us to lower our interest rates have 808 area code and the number, but, the company name on the TV screen is not from a credit card company.  We do not answer the phone unless we know the person or company, or, we just wait until the answering machine goes on and we listen to the message.  If we know who it is, we answer, otherwise, we don't.  
Sign up at Nomorobo.com.  Good luck.

Comment: Columbus Day has EVERYTHING to do with history: the struggle over the meaning of the past determines how we think of the present.  The discourse of history is always already politicized. Social forms, including nations, that people assume to be normal and natural are really a kind of historical accident. Reality itself is historically contingent.

Complaints about how revisionists are "dividing us" are really just cries of anguish as the assumptions that support certain historically contingent visions of reality are debunked and demystified. In other words, the "divisions" have always been there; it's just that they always benefitted those on one side or the other, and so were assumed to be normal and natural by the beneficiaries.

Any number of examples of this could be adduced: the "discovery of America" by Europeans, the Puritan vision of the "city on a hill" as a model of American nationhood, Manifest Destiny, American exceptionalism, white supremacy, etc.

Comment: There was an article in the Globe a few weeks ago about this.  Cost of solar panels is indeed coming down sharply mostly due to lower cost of raw materials vs cost savings due to increased production.  The problem is that in Canada, the panels themselves only make up less than 25% of the cost of the whole project.  Most of the cost is in the land and labour required to install  these eyesores.  So, the cost of panels can continue to fall and it won't really make any difference in the total cost of the project.

Wind/solar are only currently viable (with heavy government subsidies) in countries where land is cheap, labour costs are very low and the sun shines all the time.  Unfortunately, that rules out most of the US and Canada.  The author failed to mention that only 2% of wind/solar builds around the world are competitive w/o government subsidies and that is unlikely to change.

Nuclear backed up with clean burning natural gas and hydro (where avail.) are still the best option.

Comment: Perhaps because the courts have ruled that there is a duty to consult and accommodate Aboriginal groups on such matters as a result of the Constitution?

In Canada, the duty to consult and accommodate with Aboriginal peoples arises when the Crown (federal and/or provincial) contemplates actions or decisions that may affect an Aboriginal person's Aboriginal or Treaty rights which are entrenched in our Constitution - you know the supreme law of the land. This duty arises most often in the context of natural resource extraction and transport.

See:
Haida Nation v. British Columbia (Minister of Forests) 2004 SCC 73
Mikisew Cree First Nation v Canada (Minister of Canadian Heritage), 2005 SCC 69
Taku River Tlingit First Nation v British Columbia (Project Assessment Director), 2004 SCC 74, [2004]

And most recently in 2014 in an 8-0 decision the SCOC edged right up to the existence of a veto held by Aboriginal groups affected in Tsilhqot'in Nation v British Columbia 2014 SCC 44

Comment: Looking at the UK as an outsider, one is struck by the implicit desire of the peoples of several of its historic national component parts and of several of the regions of England for greater internal self-government and the desire of many others in England that these peripheral provincials (as seen by too many of these English) be disregarded on this matter.

It follows that a federal solution would serve the UK well but that this solution is rejected by the dominant English majority who see a unitary State governed from Westminster and reflecting English interests as being entirely satisfactory.

How all this will play out against the backdrop of a Conservative Government, lacking significant representation outside England, backing zombi-like towards a hard Brexit (where a decidedly soft Brexit was touted during the Referendum and narrowly won) is anyone's guess.

Little good will come of this directionless turmoil.

Comment: The video states that the Electoral College was established in 1787 in Article II of the Constitution of the United states. No such organ is established in the Constitution of the United States. Article II, Section 1 states, "Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors, equal to the whole Number of Senators and Representatives to which the State may be entitled in the Congress: but no Senator or Representative, or Person holding an Office of Trust or Profit under the United States, shall be appointed an Elector."

The quotation from Hamilton comes from Federalist No. 68, not the Constitution of the United States, a reading of which could describe the effort to keep either of these candidates from office.

Good luck Democrats, this is an appeal to constitutional originalism. If you succeed in selling this idea, Republicans will have license to rip the rug right out from underneath over a century of progress. Every yin has a yang.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: I believe what Mr. Glucklich is referring to was the levy is a rate per 1,000 in value on a property.  as the value of the property goes up, the amount of the tax increases.  The rate indeed stays the same, but the actual tax amount increases year-by-year as property values increase.
The rate is $1.28 per $1,000 value.  My taxes for this levy where $89 in 2006.  It's increased every year in amount to now be $227.
I am personally for renewing the levy, as the results within Springfield have been good in my opinion.

Comment: The format does not allow significant outside the box discussion. It is “focused” on a problem created by traditional structure with limits to discussion that only allow superficial or limited ideas so we will be discussing the same things in 30 years except innovative disruptive forces are acting that will change the structure without a lot of control. That change may not benefit everyone so public education will not act as an equalizer which has benefited us in the past.
The problems such as quality education for all children, teacher shortages, and funding would have all been minimized had a process of moving to individualization with materials and methods being funded by federal and state agencies instead of partially funded mandates. Those mandates have tended to reduce educational quality while increasing costs. Most would agree the reform and accountability measures which have cost the state over 2 billion have reduced education quality and contributed to the teacher shortage.
